title: Global Trade
text:
Getty Images

While the former boss of the World Trade Organisation believes it is possible for the UK and the EU to negotiate a free trade agreement in 13 months (see post at 07:37), Dmitry Grozoubinski isn't so sure.

Mr Grozoubinski, a former Australian WTO trade negotiator, says it is simply not a matter of using chunks the existing trade rules.

He tells the Today programme: "The fundamental principal of the single market is that the rules are agreed and then the European Court of Justice arbitrates those rules.

"The UK by leaving the EU is essentially removing that linchpin."

He says: "There is a misconception that a free trade agreement with Europe will be easier because there is alignment of the rules right now but free trade agreements aren't about what the rules are today, they are about how the rules are set for tomorrow and what the procedures and limits on that are.

"So unfortunately it is quite a difficult process."
